Gradient Statistics Aware Power Control for Over-the-Air Federated Learning

Naifu Zhang and Meixia Tao N. Zhang and M. Tao are with the Department of Electronic Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, 200240, P. R. China. (email: arthaslery@sjtu.edu.cn; mxtao@sjtu.edu.cn.). Part of this work is presented at IEEE ICC 2020 workshop [1]
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a promising technique that enables many edge devices to train a machine learning model collaboratively in wireless networks. By exploiting the superposition nature of wireless waveforms, over-the-air computation (AirComp) can accelerate model aggregation and hence facilitate communication-efficient FL. Due to channel fading, power control is crucial in AirComp. Prior works assume that the signals to be aggregated from each device, i.e., local gradients have identical statistics. In FL, however, gradient statistics vary over both training iterations and feature dimensions, and are unknown in advance. This paper studies the power control problem for over-the-air FL by taking gradient statistics into account. The goal is to minimize the aggregation error by optimizing the transmit power at each device subject to peak power constraints. We obtain the optimal policy in closed form when gradient statistics are given. Notably, we show that the optimal transmit power is continuous and monotonically decreases with the squared multivariate coefficient of variation (SMCV) of gradient vectors. We then propose a method to estimate gradient statistics with negligible communication cost. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed gradient-statistics-aware power control achieves higher test accuracy than the existing schemes for a wide range of scenarios.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, over-the-air computation, power control, fading channel.

I Introduction

The proliferation of mobile devices such as smartphones, tablets, and wearable devices has revolutionized peopleâ€™s daily lives. Due to the growing computation and sensing capabilities of these devices, a wealth of data has been generated each day. This has promoted a wide range of artificial intelligence (AI) applications such as image recognition and natural language processing. Traditional machine learning procedures, including both training and inference, are carried out through cloud computing on a centralized data center that has full access to the entire data set. Wireless edge devices are thus required to upload their collected raw data to the center, which can be very costly in terms of energy and bandwidth consumption, and unfavorable due to response delay and privacy concerns. It is thus increasingly desired to let edge devices engage in the learning process by keeping the raw data locally and performing training/inference either collaboratively or individually. This emerging technology is known as Edge Machine Learning [2] or Edge Intelligence [3].

Federated learning (FL)[4, 5, 6, 7] is a new edge learning framework that enables many edge devices to collaboratively train a machine learning model without exchanging datasets under the coordination of an edge server in wireless networks. Compared with traditional learning at a centralized data center, FL offers several distinct advantages, such as preserving privacy, reducing network congestion, and leveraging distributed on-device computation. In FL, each edge device downloads a shared model from the edge server, computes an update to the current model by learning from its local dataset, then sends this update to the edge server. Therein, the updates are averaged to improve the shared model. FL has recently attracted significant attention from both academia and industry, such as [8, 9, 10, 11].

The main bottleneck in FL is the communication cost since a large number of participating edge devices send their updates to the edge server at each round of the model training. Existing methods to obtain communication-efficient FL can be mainly divided into three categories: model parameter compression [12, 13], gradient sparsification [14, 15], and infrequent local update [4, 16]. Nevertheless, the communication cost of FL is still proportional to the number of edge devices, and thus inefficient in large-scale environment. Recently, a fast model aggregation approach is proposed for synchronous FL by applying the over-the-air computation (AirComp) principle [17], such as in [18, 19, 20, 21]. This is accomplished by exploiting the waveform superposition nature of the wireless medium to compute the desired function of the distributed local gradients (i.e., the weighted average function) by concurrent transmission. Such AirComp-based FL, referred to as over-the-air FL in this work, can dramatically save the uplink communication bandwidth.

Due to the channel fading, device selection and power control are crucial to achieve a reliable and high-performance over-the-air FL. In [22], the authors jointly optimize the transmit power at edge devices and the receive scaling factor (known as denoising factor) at the edge server for minimizing the mean square error (MSE) of the aggregated signal. It is shown that the optimal transmit power in static channels exhibits a threshold-based structure. Namely, each device applies channel-inversion power control if its quality indicator exceeds the optimal threshold, and applies full power transmission otherwise. The work [22], however, is purely for AirComp-based signal aggregation (not in the context of learning), where the signal on each device is assumed to be independent and identically distributed (IID) with zero mean and unit variance. For AirComp-based gradient aggregation in FL, the work [19] introduces a truncation-based approach for excluding the edge devices with deep fading channels to strike a good balance between learning performance and aggregation error. The work [18] proposes a joint device selection and receiver beamforming design method to find the maximum number of selected devices with MSE requirements to improve the learning performance. As in [22], it is assumed in both [18] and [19] that the signal (i.e., the local gradient) to be aggregated from each device is IID, and normalized with zero mean and unit variance. By exploiting the sparsity pattern in gradient vectors, the work [21] projects the gradient estimate in each device into a low-dimensional vector and transmits only the important gradient entries while accumulating the error from previous iterations. Therein, a channel-inversion like power control scheme, similar to those in [22, 19, 18] is designed so that the gradient vectors sent from the selected devices are aligned at the edge server.

Note that all the exiting works on power control for over-the-air FL have overlooked the following statistical characteristics of gradients: the gradient distribution over training iterations is not necessarily identical; and even in the same iteration, the distribution of each entry of the gradient vector can be non-identical. A general observation is that the gradient distribution changes over iterations and is different in each feature dimension. In addition, if the gradient distribution is unknown for each device, normalizing the gradient to a distribution with zero mean and unit variance is infeasible. As such, due to the neglect of the above characteristics of gradient distribution, the existing power control methods for over-the-air FL may not perform efficiently in practice.

Motivated by the above issue, in this paper, we study the optimal power control problem for over-the-air FL in fading channels by taking gradient statistics into account. Our goal is to minimize the MSE of the aggregated model at each iteration, and hence improve the accuracy of FL, by jointly optimizing the transmit power at each device and the denoising factor at the edge server given the first-order and second-order statistics of gradients. The main contributions of this work are outlined below:

  • â€¢

    Optimal power control with known gradient statistics: We first derive the MSE expression of gradient aggregation at each iteration of the model training when the first-order and second-order statistics of the gradient vectors are known. We then formulate a joint optimization problem of transmit power at edge devices and denoising factor at the edge server for MSE minimization subject to individual peak power constraints at edge devices. By decomposing this non-convex problem into subproblems defined on different subregions, we obtain the optimal power control strategy in closed form. Unlike the existing threshold-based power control for normalized signal in [22], our optimal transmit power depends not only on the channel quality and noise power, but also heavily on the gradient statistics. In particular, we find that the relative dispersion of the gradient values, i.e., the squared multivariate coefficient of variation (SMCV) of the gradient vectors, plays a key role in the optimal transmit power control. Specifically, we prove that the optimal transmit power of each device is a continuous and monotonically decreasing function of the gradient SMCV.

  • â€¢

    Optimal power control in special cases: In the special case where the gradient SMCV approaches infinity, which could happen when the model training converges and/or the dataset is highly non-IID, we show that there is an optimal threshold for the device aggregation capability, below which the device transmits with full power and above which it transmits at the power to equalize the weight of its gradient for aggregation to one. In the other special case where the gradient SMCV approaches zero, which could happen when the model training just begins, we show that the optimal power control is to let all the devices transmit with their peak powers.

  • â€¢

    Adaptive power control with unknown gradient statistics: We propose an adaptive power control algorithm that estimates the gradient statistics based on the historical aggregated gradients and then dynamically adjusts the power values in each iteration based on the estimation results. The communication cost consumed by estimating the gradient statistics is negligible compared to the transmission of the entire gradient vector.

To evaluate the efficiency of the proposed power control scheme, we implement the FL in PyTorch for AI applications of three datasets: MNIST, CIFAR-10 and SVHN. Experimental results demonstrate that the over-the-air FL with the proposed adaptive power control obtains higher model accuracy than the considered existing power control methods (full power transmission and threshold-based power control for normalized signal [22]). In particular, while the full power transmission performs poorly in high signal-noise ratio (SNR) region and non-IID data distribution and the threshold-based power control for normalized signal [22] performs poorly in low SNR region and IID data distribution, the proposed power control can perform very well over a wide range of scenarios by exploiting the gradient statistics.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The over-the-air FL system is modeled in Section II. Section III describes the optimal power control strategy with known gradient statistics. In Section IV, we introduce an adaptive power control scheme when the gradient statistics are unknown in advance. Section V provides experimental results. Finally we conclude the paper in Section VI.

II-C Performance Measure

Note that in deriving (8), we have used the previous assumption that the gradient elements {gk,dâ€‹(t)},âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦subscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜ğ‘‘ğ‘¡for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦\{g_{k,d}(t)\},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, are IID across devices, i.e, Î±kâ€‹(t)=ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’ˆkâ€‹(t)â€–2]=ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’ˆâ€‹(t)â€–2]=âˆ‘d=1D(Ïƒd2â€‹(t)+md2â€‹(t))subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘˜ğ‘¡2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’ˆğ‘¡2superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‘2ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘‘2ğ‘¡\alpha_{k}(t)=\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}_{k}(t)\|^{2}]=\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}(t)\|^{2}]=\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\left(\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)+m_{d}^{2}(t)\right)}.

Observing (8) closely, we find that the MSE consists of three components, representing the individual misalignment error (the first term), the composite misalignment error (the second term), and the noise-induced error (the third term), respectively. The individual misalignment error is weighted by the gradient variance âˆ‘d=1DÏƒd2â€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‘2ğ‘¡\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)} while the composite misalignment error is weighted by the gradient mean âˆ‘d=1Dmd2â€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘‘2ğ‘¡\sum_{d=1}^{D}{m_{d}^{2}(t)}. In the special case when the gradient has zero mean, the MSE in (8) reduces to that in [22] where the composite misalignment error is absent. Our objective is to minimize MSE in (8), by jointly optimizing the transmit power pkâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¡p_{k}(t) at all devices and the denoising factor Î·â€‹(t)ğœ‚ğ‘¡\eta(t) at the edge server, subject to the individual power budget in (6) at each iteration tğ‘¡t.

II-D Gradient Statistics

In general, the individual misalignment error and the composite misalignment error in MSE of the gradient aggregation (8) cannot be forced to zero simultaneously due to the peak power budget on each device. It is difficult to capture the tradeoff between the two errors by directly using their respective weights, namely, the gradient variance and gradient mean. To tackle this issue, we introduce two alternative parameters of gradient statistics in this subsection.

Let Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) denote the mean squared norm (MSN) of ğ’ˆâ€‹(t)ğ’ˆğ‘¡\bm{g}(t), i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’ˆâ€‹(t)â€–2]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’ˆğ‘¡2\mathbb{E}[\|\bm{g}(t)\|^{2}], which is given by

Î±â€‹(t)=âˆ‘d=1D(Ïƒd2â€‹(t)+md2â€‹(t)),ğ›¼ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‘2ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘‘2ğ‘¡\alpha(t)=\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\bigg{(}\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)+m_{d}^{2}(t)\bigg{)}}, (9)

and let Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) denote the squared multivariate coefficient of variation (SMCV) of ğ’ˆâ€‹(t)ğ’ˆğ‘¡\bm{g}(t), which is given by

Î²â€‹(t)=âˆ‘d=1DÏƒd2â€‹(t)âˆ‘d=1Dmd2â€‹(t).ğ›½ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‘2ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘‘2ğ‘¡\beta(t)=\frac{\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)}}{\sum_{d=1}^{D}{m_{d}^{2}(t)}}. (10)

While Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) measures the average absolute value of the gradient values at iteration tğ‘¡t, Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) is a measure of relative dispersion of the gradient at iteration tğ‘¡t. In Section III-B, we shall show that the optimal transmit power is dominated by Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) and independent of Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t). Fig.Â 2 illustrates the experimental results of the alternative gradient statistics Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) of three datasets, MNIST, CIFAR-10, and SVHN, where the gradients are updated ideally without any transmission error. Both IID and non-IID partitions are considered for the training dataset and the generation of IID and non-IID data distributions is specified in Section V. Each value of Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) is obtained by averaging over 300 model trainings. It is observed that as the training time increases, the gradient MSN Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) gradually decreases and approaches to a constant while the gradient SMCV Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) keeps increasing from a small starting point for all the three datasets. Intuitively, in SGD-based learning, the gradient mean {mdâ€‹(t)}subscriptğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘¡\{m_{d}(t)\} is large at the begining, then gradually approaches to zero when the model converges; the gradient variance {Ïƒd2â€‹(t)}superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‘2ğ‘¡\{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t)\}, on the other hand, remains approximately unchanged due to the randomness of local datasets throughout the training process. As a result, according to the definitions in (9) and (10), the absolute squared norm of the gradient, Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t), decreases during the training and converges to a constant , but the relative dispersion of the gradient, Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t), is very small when the training just begins and then gradually increases when the training continues. It is also observed that Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) in non-IID partition are much larger than those in IID partition for all the three datasets. This indicates that the gradient distribution with non-IID dataset partition is more dispersive than that with IID dataset partition as expected. Note that the gradient MSN Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) of CIFAR-10 and SVHN datasets are larger than MNIST dataset. This is because the dimensions of model parameters for training CIFAR-10 and SVHN datasets are larger than MNIST dataset.

By (9) and (10), the MSE in (8) can be rewritten as (omitting the constant coefficient 1/K21superscriptğ¾21/K^{2} for convenience)

MSEâ€‹(t)=MSEğ‘¡absent\displaystyle\text{MSE}(t)= Î²â€‹(t)â€‹Î±â€‹(t)Î²â€‹(t)+1â€‹âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦(pkâ€‹(t)â€‹|hkâ€‹(t)|Î·â€‹(t)â€‹Î±â€‹(t)âˆ’1)2ğ›½ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘¡12\displaystyle\frac{\beta(t)\alpha(t)}{\beta(t)+1}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{\left(\frac{\sqrt{p_{k}(t)}|h_{k}(t)|}{\sqrt{\eta(t)\alpha(t)}}-1\right)^{2}}
+Î±â€‹(t)Î²â€‹(t)+1â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦pkâ€‹(t)â€‹|hkâ€‹(t)|Î·â€‹(t)â€‹Î±â€‹(t)âˆ’K)2+Dâ€‹Ïƒn2Î·â€‹(t).ğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ›½ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptâ„ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘¡ğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ¾2ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2ğœ‚ğ‘¡\displaystyle+\frac{\alpha(t)}{\beta(t)+1}{\left(\frac{\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\sqrt{p_{k}(t)}|h_{k}(t)|}{\sqrt{\eta(t)\alpha(t)}}-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta(t)}. (11)

It is seen from (11) that while the gradient MSN Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) appears linearly in the weights of both individual and composite misalignment errors, the gradient SMCV Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) plays a more distinguishing role in the MSE expression. In particular, when Î²â€‹(t)â†’0â†’ğ›½ğ‘¡0\beta(t)\rightarrow 0, which could be the case when the model training just begins (as could be verified by Fig.Â 2, the individual signal misalignment error can be neglected. When Î²â€‹(t)â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t)\rightarrow\infty, which could be the case when the model training converges or during the middle of the training when the dataset is highly non-IID (as could be verified by Fig.Â 2, the composite signal misalignment error disappears.

Finally, we can formally conclude the following property of the optimal transmit power function with respect to the gradient statistics and noise variance.

Property 1

The optimal transmit power ğ©âˆ—â€‹(Î±,Î²,Ïƒn2)superscriptğ©ğ›¼ğ›½subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) of problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} is a continuous and monotonic vector function in the entire domain of (Î±â‰¥0,Î²â‰¥0,Ïƒn2â‰¥0)formulae-sequenceğ›¼0formulae-sequenceğ›½0subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›0(\alpha\geq 0,\beta\geq 0,\sigma^{2}_{n}\geq 0). Moreover, it decreases with Î²ğ›½\beta, increases with Ïƒn2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2\sigma_{n}^{2}, and remain unchanged w.r.t. Î±ğ›¼\alpha.

Take a system with K=6ğ¾6K=6 devices for illustration. Fig.Â 3 shows the optimal transmit power of each device pkâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p^{*}_{k} as a function of gradient SMCV Î²ğ›½\beta, together with the corresponding optimal index lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*}. The results are based on one channel realization of each device, |hk|subscriptâ„ğ‘˜|h_{k}|, taken independently from normalized Rayleigh distribution, given by [0.50,0.82,0.85,1.16,2.09,2.83]0.500.820.851.162.092.83[0.50,0.82,0.85,1.16,2.09,2.83]. The peak power constraint of each device is set to be same, resulting in the same average received SNR, given by PkDâ€‹Ïƒn2=5 dB and 10 dBsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›25 dB and 10 dB\frac{P_{k}}{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}=\mbox{5 dB and 10 dB}, respectively. The gradient MSN Î±=0.25ğ›¼0.25\alpha=0.25, noise variance Ïƒ2=1superscriptğœ21\sigma^{2}=1 and D=1ğ·1D=1. Fig.Â 3 clearly verifies that the optimal transmit power ğ’‘âˆ—â€‹(Î±,Î²,Ïƒn2)superscriptğ’‘ğ›¼ğ›½subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘›\bm{p}^{*}(\alpha,\beta,\sigma^{2}_{n}) is a continuous and monotonically decreasing vector function of the gradient SMCV Î²ğ›½\beta. In particular, it is seen that when Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0, all the devices transmit with full power; when beta increases, the power of the devices with large aggregation capability decreases, then gradually approaches a constant, and the larger the aggregation capability is, the smaller the constant transmit power is. In addition, it is observed from Fig.Â 3 that when the peak power budget increases, more devices can transmit with less power than its peak value. Equivalently, the optimal transmit power decreases when the noise variance decreases.

III-C Power Control Problem for Special Cases

In this subsection, we show that the threshold-based power control in [22] and the full power transmission are two special cases of the optimal power control policy where the gradient SMCV Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty and Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0, respectively.

III-C1 Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty

As discussed in Section II-D, this case may happen when the model training converges and/or the dataset is highly non-IID. In this case, the problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} reduces to the power control problem in [22]. The optimal solution when Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty can be reduced directly from the solution of problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1}. Specifically, by letting Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty in Theorem 1, we have the following Corollary,

Corollary 1

The optimal transmit power when Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty has a threshold-based structure, i.e.,

pkâˆ—={Pk,âˆ€kâˆˆ{1,â€¦,lâˆ—}Î±â€‹Î·âˆ—|hk|2,âˆ€kâˆˆ{lâˆ—+1,â€¦,K},superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜casessubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜1â€¦superscriptğ‘™ğ›¼superscriptğœ‚superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜2for-allğ‘˜superscriptğ‘™1â€¦ğ¾p_{k}^{*}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}P_{k},&\forall{k}\in\{1,...,l^{*}\}\\ \frac{\alpha\eta^{*}}{|h_{k}|^{2}},&\forall{k}\in\{l^{*}+1,...,K\},\end{array}\right. (24)

where the optimal denoising factor is given as

Î·âˆ—=(Î±â€‹âˆ‘i=1lâˆ—Ci2+Dâ€‹Ïƒn2Î±â€‹âˆ‘i=1lâˆ—Ci)2,superscriptğœ‚superscriptğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1superscriptğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–2ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1superscriptğ‘™subscriptğ¶ğ‘–2\displaystyle\eta^{*}=\bigg{(}\frac{\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{l^{*}}{C_{i}^{2}}+D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\alpha\sum_{i=1}^{l^{*}}{C_{i}}}\bigg{)}^{2}, (25)

and lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*} is given in (20).

Note that the optimal denoising factor Î·âˆ—superscriptğœ‚\eta^{*} when Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty can be interpreted as the threshold, since whether a device transmits with full power or not depends entirely on the comparison between its aggregation capability Cksubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜C_{k} and Î·âˆ—superscriptğœ‚\sqrt{\eta^{*}}. Nevertheless, such threshold interpretation of Î·âˆ—superscriptğœ‚\eta^{*} does not hold for problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} with general Î²ğ›½\beta.

III-C2 Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0

As discussed in Section II-D, Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0 could happen when the model training just begins and the dataset is IID. In this case, the individual signal misalignment error disappears in the MSE expressions. The original MSE expression reduces to Î±â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Gkâ€‹(pk,Î·)âˆ’K)2+Dâ€‹Ïƒn2Î·ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğœ‚ğ¾2ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2ğœ‚\alpha{\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta}. Note that the optimal solution when Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0 cannot be reduced directly from Theorem 1 by simply letting Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0 as lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*} is unknown.

Corollary 2

The optimal transmit power when Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0 is full power transmission, i.e.,

pkâˆ—=Pk,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦\displaystyle p_{k}^{*}=P_{k},~{}~{}~{}\forall{k}\in\mathcal{K}, (26)

and the optimal denoising factor is given by

Î·âˆ—=(Î±â€‹(âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’¦Ci)2+Dâ€‹Ïƒn2Î±â€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’¦Ci)2.superscriptğœ‚superscriptğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ’¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘–2ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2ğ›¼ğ¾subscriptğ‘–ğ’¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘–2\displaystyle\eta^{*}=\bigg{(}\frac{\alpha\big{(}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{i}}\big{)}^{2}+D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\alpha K\sum_{i\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{i}}}\bigg{)}^{2}. (27)
Proof:

It is obvious that the optimal denoising factor satisfies Î·âˆ—â‰¥âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Cksuperscriptğœ‚subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜\eta^{*}\geq\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{k}}. For any denoising factor Î·â‰¥1K2â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Ck)2ğœ‚1superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘˜2\eta\geq\frac{1}{K^{2}}\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{C_{k}}\right)^{2}, it must hold that âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Gkâ€‹(pk,Î·)â‰¤Ksubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğœ‚ğ¾\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)\leq K when Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0. Therefore, for minimizing the composite signal misalignment error (âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Gkâ€‹(pk,Î·)âˆ’K)2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğœ‚ğ¾2\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(p_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}, all the devices should transmit with full power, i.e., pkâˆ—=Pk,âˆ€kâˆˆğ’¦formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜for-allğ‘˜ğ’¦p_{k}^{*}=P_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. The MSE expression Î±â€‹(âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Gkâ€‹(Pk,Î·)âˆ’K)2+Dâ€‹Ïƒn2Î·ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦subscriptğºğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğœ‚ğ¾2ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2ğœ‚\alpha{\left(\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}G_{k}(P_{k},\eta)-K\right)^{2}}+\frac{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}{\eta} is a unary quadratic function about 1Î·1ğœ‚\frac{1}{\sqrt{\eta}}, thus it is easy to derive the optimal solution (27) in closed form. Corollary 2 is thus proven. âˆ

Note that lâˆ—=Ksuperscriptğ‘™ğ¾l^{*}=K when Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0 based on the proof. The direction of the gradient vector received from each device at the edge server is independent to the power of the transmitting device. Thus, increasing the power of all devices can reduce the noise-induced error when the composite signal misalignment error is fixed.

Remark 2

The threshold-based power control in [22] and the full power transmission are sub-optimal in general and they are optimal only when Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty and Î²â†’0â†’ğ›½0\beta\rightarrow 0, respectively. In particular, the threshold-based power control can only perform efficiently when the model training converges and the dataset is highly non-IID, the full power transmission can only perform efficiently when the model training just begins and the dataset is IID. Compared with these two schemes, our proposed power control policy is always optimal. These findings shall be validated via experimental results in Section V.

IV Adaptive Power Control with Unknown Gradient Statistics

In this section, we consider the practical scenario where the gradient statistics Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) are unknown. We propose a method to estimate Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) in each time block and then devise an adaptive power control scheme based on the optimal solution of problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} by using the estimated Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t).

IV-A Parameters Estimation

In this subsection, we propose a method to estimate Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) at each time block tğ‘¡t directly based on their definitions in (9) and (10), respectively.

IV-A1 Estimation of Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t)

Let Bkâ€‹(t)â‰œâ€–ğ’ˆkâ€‹(t)â€–â‰œsubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘¡normsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘˜ğ‘¡B_{k}(t)\triangleq\|\bm{g}_{k}(t)\| denote the gradient norm of device kğ‘˜k at iteration tğ‘¡t. At the end of each round of local training, we let each device transmit its gradient norm Bkâ€‹(t)subscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘¡B_{k}(t) to the edge server before sending the gradient vector ğ’ˆkâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{g}_{k}(t). Note that the communication cost of transmitting Bkâ€‹(t)subscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘¡B_{k}(t) is negligible compared with that of transmitting the gradient ğ’ˆkâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{g}_{k}(t). This is because the gradient norm Bkâ€‹(t)subscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘¡B_{k}(t) is a scalar while the gradient ğ’ˆkâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{g}_{k}(t) is a vector whose dimension Dğ·D can be very large333In the considered datasets for experimental validation, Dğ·D is in the order of 104superscript10410^{4}.. By definition (9), we can estimate the gradient MSN as the mean of the squared gradient norms across all the participating devices:

Î±^â€‹(t)=1Kâ€‹âˆ‘kâˆˆğ’¦Bk2â€‹(t).^ğ›¼ğ‘¡1ğ¾subscriptğ‘˜ğ’¦superscriptsubscriptğµğ‘˜2ğ‘¡\hat{\alpha}(t)=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}{B_{k}^{2}(t)}. (28)

IV-A2 Estimation of Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t)

By definition in (10), the gradient SMCV Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) depends on mdâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘¡m_{d}(t) and Ïƒdâ€‹(t)subscriptğœğ‘‘ğ‘¡\sigma_{d}(t). Before each device sending its gradient at time block tğ‘¡t, we cannot estimate Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) in advance. However, from the experimental results of real datasets in Fig.Â 2, it can be observed that Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) is highly correlated among adjacent iterations. Thus we propose to estimate Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) using the aggregated gradient at time block tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1 as below

Î²^â€‹(t)=Î±^â€‹(tâˆ’1)âˆ’âˆ‘d=1Dg^d2â€‹(tâˆ’1)âˆ‘d=1Dg^d2â€‹(tâˆ’1),^ğ›½ğ‘¡^ğ›¼ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘‘2ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘1ğ·superscriptsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘‘2ğ‘¡1\hat{\beta}(t)=\frac{\hat{\alpha}(t-1)-\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\hat{g}_{d}^{2}(t-1)}}{\sum_{d=1}^{D}{\hat{g}_{d}^{2}(t-1)}}, (29)

where Î±^â€‹(tâˆ’1)^ğ›¼ğ‘¡1\hat{\alpha}(t-1) estimates âˆ‘dÏƒd2â€‹(tâˆ’1)+md2â€‹(tâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘‘2ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘‘2ğ‘¡1\sum_{d}{\sigma_{d}^{2}(t-1)+m_{d}^{2}(t-1)} and âˆ‘dg^d2â€‹(tâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘‘superscriptsubscript^ğ‘”ğ‘‘2ğ‘¡1\sum_{d}{\hat{g}_{d}^{2}(t-1)} estimates âˆ‘dmd2â€‹(tâˆ’1)subscriptğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘šğ‘‘2ğ‘¡1\sum_{d}{m_{d}^{2}(t-1)}.

IV-B FL with Adaptive Power Control

In this subsection, we propose the FL process with adaptive power control, which is presented in Algorithm 1. The algorithm has three steps. First, each device locally takes one step of SGD on the current model using its local dataset (line 5). After that each device calculates the norm of its local gradient and uploads it to the edge server with conventional digital transmission (line 6 and line 7). Second, the edge server estimates parameters Î±â€‹(t)ğ›¼ğ‘¡\alpha(t) and Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) based on the received gradient norm at time block tğ‘¡t and historical aggregated gradient (line 9 and line 16). Then the optimal transmit power and denoising factor are obtained based on (21) and (22), respectively (line 10). Third, the edge server informs the optimal transmit power to each device and each device transmits local gradient with the assigned power simultaneously using AirComp to the edge server in an analog manner (line 12-14).

Note that the computational complexity of finding the optimal power control in Algorithm 1 mainly consists of the time complexity of sorting devices by aggregation capability, which is Oâ€‹(Kâ€‹logâ¡K)ğ‘‚ğ¾ğ¾O(K\log{K}), and the time complexity of finding lâˆ—superscriptğ‘™l^{*} by Lemma 4, which is Oâ€‹(K)ğ‘‚ğ¾O(K). It is approximately the same as the existing scheme [22]. The additional overhead introduced by our method when compared with [22] lies at the communication cost for each device to send the gradient norm Bkâ€‹(t)subscriptğµğ‘˜ğ‘¡B_{k}(t) to the edge server as shown in line 7 of Algorithm 1, which is negligible as discussed in Section IV-A.

V Experimental Results

In this section, we provide experimental results to validate the performance of the proposed power control for AirComp-based FL over fading channels.

V-A Experiment Setup

We conducted experiments on a simulated environment where the number of edge devices is K=10ğ¾10K=10 if not specified otherwise. The wireless channels from each device to the edge server follow IID Rayleigh fading, such that hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k}â€™s are modeled as IID complex Gaussian variables with zero mean and unit variance. For each device kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K}, we define SNRk=ğ”¼â€‹[Pkâ€‹|hk|2Dâ€‹Ïƒn2]=PkDâ€‹Ïƒn2subscriptSNRğ‘˜ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘˜2ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ·superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘›2\mbox{SNR}_{k}=\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{P_{k}|h_{k}|^{2}}{D\sigma_{n}^{2}}\right]=\frac{P_{k}}{D\sigma_{n}^{2}} as the average received SNR.

V-A1 Baselines

We compare the proposed adaptive power control scheme with the following baseline approaches:

  • â€¢

    Error-free transmission: the aggregated gradient is updated perfectly without any transmission error. This is equivalent to the centralized SGD algorithm.

  • â€¢

    Power control with known statistics: We assume that the gradient statistics are known in advance at the beginning of the training, and then apply the proposed power control. In our experiments, the actual gradient statistics are obtained from 100010001000 gradient samples without transmission error.

  • â€¢

    Threshold-based power control in [22]: this is the power control scheme given in [22], which assumed that signals are normalized. Note that it is actually the special case of our proposed power control scheme with Î²â†’âˆâ†’ğ›½\beta\rightarrow\infty by considering the individual misalignment error only in problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1}.

  • â€¢

    Full power transmission: all devices transmit with full power Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} and the edge server applies the optimal denoising factor in (22), where lâˆ—=Ksuperscriptğ‘™ğ¾l^{*}=K.

V-A2 Datasets

We evaluate the training of convolutional neural network on three datasets: MNIST, CIFAR-10 and SVHN. MNIST dataset consists of 10 categories ranging from digit 0 to 9 and a total of 70000 labeled data samples (60000 for training and 10000 for testing). CIFAR-10 dataset includes 60000 color images (50000 for training and 10000 for testing) of 10 different types of objects. SVHN is a real-world image dataset for developing machine learning and object recognition algorithms with minimal requirement on data preprocessing and formatting, which includes 99289 labeled data samples (73257 for training and 26032 for testing).

V-A3 Data Distribution

To study the impact of the SMCV of gradient Î²ğ›½\beta for optimal transmit power, we simulate two types of dataset partitions among the mobile devices, i.e., the IID setting and non-IID one. For the former, we randomly partition the training samples into 100100100 equal shards, each of which is assigned to one particular device. While for the latter, we first sort the data by digit label, divide it into 200200200 equal shards, and randomly assign 222 shards to each device.

V-A4 Neural network and hyper-parameters

In all our experiments, we adopt the convolutional neural network (the number of layers is 11). The hyper-parameters are set as follows: momentum optimizer is 0.5, the number of local updates between two global aggregations is 1, local batch size is 10 and learning rate Î³=0.01ğ›¾0.01\gamma=0.01.

V-B Experimental Results

Fig.Â 4 compares the test accuracy for the three considered datasets with IID dataset partition and non-IID dataset partition, respectively, where the average received SNR is set as 10 dB for all devices. It is observed that the performance gap to the scheme with known gradient statistics is very small, which indicates the proposed methods for estimating gradient statistics are effective. It is also observed that the model accuracy of the proposed power control scheme is better than threshold-based power control and full power transmission. From Fig.Â 2, we have known that the averaged gradient SMCV Î²â€‹(t)ğ›½ğ‘¡\beta(t) in the IID dataset partition is less than that in the non-IID dataset partition and it increases over iterations. Threshold-based power control suffers significant accuracy loss in the IID partition or at the beginning of training. This is because in this case, the gradient SMCV is small and thus the MSE is dominated by the composite misalignment error. As a result, threshold-based power control that considers the individual misalignment error only is much inferior. Besides, full power transmission suffers significant accuracy loss in the non-IID partition or at the end of training. This is because the gradient SMCV is large and therefore the full power transmission scheme fails to minimize the individual misalignment error that dominates the MSE in this case.

Fig.Â 5 illustrates the test accuracy for MNIST with non-IID data partition at the average received SNR=5 dBSNR5 dB\mbox{SNR}=\mbox{5 dB}. It is observed that the overall performance of the proposed scheme is still better than two baseline approaches at low SNR region. In specific, full power transmission performs better than threshold-based power control scheme. This is mainly because when the noise variance is large, full power transmission can strongly suppress noise error that dominates the MSE.

Finally, Fig.Â 6 compares the test accuracy of different power control schemes at varying number of devices Kğ¾K. Here, MNIST dataset with non-IID partition is used, the average received SNR of all the devices is set as SNRk=10subscriptSNRğ‘˜10\mbox{SNR}_{k}=10 dB and the results are averaged over 505050 model trainings. First, it is observed that the test accuracy achieved by all the four schemes increases when the number of participating devices Kğ¾K increases but cannot increase further when Kğ¾K is large enough. In particular, the test accuracy of all the considered schemes keeps unchanged when Kâ‰¥30ğ¾30K\geq 30, due to the fact that the edge server can aggregate enough data for averaging. Second, the proposed scheme outperforms both of threshold-based power control and full power transmission throughout the whole regime of Kğ¾K. Full power transmission approaches threshold-based power control when Kğ¾K is small (i.e., K=4ğ¾4K=4 in Fig.Â 6), but the performance compromises as Kğ¾K increases, due to the lack of power adaptation to reduce the misalignment error.

VI Conclusion

This work studied the power control optimization problem for the over-the-air federated learning over fading channels by taking the gradient statistics into account. The optimal power control policy is derived in closed form when the first- and second-order gradient statistics are known. It is shown that the optimal transmit power on each device decreases with gradient SMCV and increases with noise variance. In the special cases where Î²ğ›½\beta approaches infinity and zero, the optimal transmit power reduces to threshold-based power control and full power transmission, respectively. We propose an adaptive power control algorithm that dynamically adjusts the transmit power in each iteration based on the estimation results. Experimental results show that our proposed adaptive power control scheme outperforms the existing schemes. In the future work, we can further exploit the gradient statistics for joint power control and beamforming when each edge device has multiple antennas.

Appendix A Proof of Lemma 1

We prove this Lemma by contradiction. Suppose the optimal denoising factor Î·âˆ—â‰¤C12superscriptğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ¶12\eta^{*}\leq C_{1}^{2}. Appendix C Proof of Lemma 3

To prove this lemma is equal to proving that if the optimal solution ğ’‘~lâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptbold-~ğ’‘ğ‘™\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} of the sub-problem defined in the relaxed subregion â„³l~~subscriptâ„³ğ‘™\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}} does not lie in â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}, the global optimal solution pâˆ—superscriptğ‘p^{*} of problem ğ’«1subscriptğ’«1\mathcal{P}_{1} must not lie in subregion â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}. First, we prove that ğ’‘~lâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptbold-~ğ’‘ğ‘™\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the only local minimum point in â„³l~~subscriptâ„³ğ‘™\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}. Note that the derivative of a differentiable function at the local minimum point must be 0, and ğ’‘~lâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptbold-~ğ’‘ğ‘™\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the only zero point of the derivative of (14a) w.r.t. pksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{k}. Hence, ğ’‘~lâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptbold-~ğ’‘ğ‘™\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} is the only local minimum point in â„³l~~subscriptâ„³ğ‘™\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}. Now, we prove Lemma 3 by contradiction. We assume that ğ’‘~lâˆ—âˆ‰â„³lsubscriptsuperscriptbold-~ğ’‘ğ‘™subscriptâ„³ğ‘™\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l}\notin\mathcal{M}_{l}, then there is no local minimum point in â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l} due to â„³lâŠ†â„³l~subscriptâ„³ğ‘™~subscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}\subseteq\tilde{\mathcal{M}_{l}}. If ğ’‘âˆ—superscriptğ’‘\bm{p}^{*} lies in â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}, ğ’‘âˆ—superscriptğ’‘\bm{p}^{*} must be a local minimum point due to the fact that ğ’‘âˆ—superscriptğ’‘\bm{p}^{*} is the minimum point in â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l} and ğ’‘âˆ—superscriptğ’‘\bm{p}^{*} is an interior point of â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}. It contradicts that there is no local minimum point in â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}. Therefore, if ğ’‘~lâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptbold-~ğ’‘ğ‘™\bm{\tilde{p}}^{*}_{l} does not lie in â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}, the global optimal transmit power ğ’‘âˆ—superscriptğ’‘\bm{p}^{*} must not lie in the lğ‘™l-th subregion â„³lsubscriptâ„³ğ‘™\mathcal{M}_{l}. The proof of Lemma 3 is completed.
